awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Behavioral Drivers and Social Pathways in the Spread of the COVID-19 Omicron Variant
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the behavioral drivers and real-time changes in behavior affecting the potential transmission of the Omicron variant off the SARS-COV-2 respiratory virus during critical moments of crowding, mingling, and interacting in close quarters. It aims specifically to understand the social complexities of ritual and travel that reduce or heighten the risk of COVID-19 infection. Data from the study contributes intellectually to high-priority biomedical research that seeks to advance public health interventions. This study will provide critical information for the development of public health programs and guidelines that address the risks communities face with the Omicron variant. The project also provides training for graduate and undergraduate students in methods of rigorous, scientific data collection and analysis.

This study tests existing theoretical presumptions that people disregard state-mandated health regulations at moments when cultural, religious, and social rites of solidarity and obligations take priority. The emergence of the highly contagious Omicron variant during a peak travel season provides an opportunity to map transmission pathways in real time. This project triangulates ephemeral data regarding holiday travel and religious ceremonies with social network information and household demographics. Data from behavioral observations of religious ceremonies will yield information about social practices compared with state-mandated regulations of masking, vaccinating, and social distancing. Data regarding social networks will yield information about linked urban-rural migrant pathways for potential disease transmission. Data from interviews will record age, ethnicity, sex, socioeconomic status, marital status, family size, and will aid in mapping migratory patterns and social networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
On 26 November 2021, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced the emergence of a new COVID-19 variant, Omicron, in South Africa and asked all countries to report initial cases immediately. Over the next four months, Omicron trended globally as a highly contagious and fast-spreading variant. News of this fourth-wave variant led to the renewal of public vaccination campaigns worldwide and spurred commitment among governments and international agencies to fast-track vaccine availability. 

Initiated at the height of this global public health campaign, this study worked with a community of Xhosa-speaking people employed in the Western Cape province of South Africa who travel to the Eastern Cape province for family and religious functions. It sought to test existing theoretical presumptions that people disregard state-mandated health regulations when cultural, ceremonial, and social rites of solidarity take priority. The study hypothesized that the more precarious a person’s social status (e.g., an unmarried as opposed to a married mother, a father whose son is not yet initiated and thus his successor is not yet identified, a vaccinated yet sick individual whose cause of illness is not known) the more likely that person is to engage in social activities (such as travel) and behaviors (such as crowding during funerals or initiation ceremonies) that do not conform with state-mandated health regulations. 

The study was conducted with elders, leaders, and household members who traveled regularly by bus between two provinces. The results reveal that most study participants face significant challenges despite their desire to take precautions that conform with public mandates. They either cannot afford to or feel pressed by family and social networks to undertake behavior that public health officials deem risky. The results also reveal a skepticism among some participants that social-behavior interventions funded through private venture philanthropies located in ‘the West’ fundamentally serve not to benefit the most globally economically marginalized but to reinforce globally entrenched political and economic inequalities. Two manuscripts have resulted from the research, one for Anthropological Quarterly and another for a book chapter. The findings from this research are critical to efforts to improve and inform a more nuanced understanding among social scientists and public policymakers about how to fund and deploy public interventions that the intended audiences, including economically precarious communities, can accept and will adopt. 

 


Last Modified: 04/17/2024
Modified by: Amy E Stambach
